messages.text:
When a package `P` is registered in two registries, `add P` correctly installs the latest available version.
However, `dev P` seems to take the git url from the first registry, either in the order of how registries were added or alphabetically.
Is there any fix/workaround for this, to use the registry with latest version when `dev`ing as well?

elements.text: When a package
P
is registered in two registries,
add P

correctly installs the latest available version.
However,
dev P

seems to take the git url from the first registry, either in the order of how registries were added or alphabetically.
Is there any fix/workaround for this, to use the registry with latest version when
dev
ing as well?

messages.text: Is it possible to "develop" a package without having the package manager attempting to download the latest version of the dependencies? I think this is the same as add(...; preserve=PRESERVE_ALL)?

elements.text: Is it possible to "develop" a package without having the package manager attempting to download the latest version of the dependencies? I think this is the same as add(...; preserve=PRESERVE_ALL)?

messages.text: `Pkg.develop` accepts the `preserve` keyword argument, just like `Pkg.add`

elements.text: Pkg.develop
accepts the
preserve
keyword argument, just like
Pkg.add

messages.text: Does that work for your use case?

elements.text: Does that work for your use case?

messages.text: It probably will, thanks! I did not see it on the documentation so I thought it would not be possible...

elements.text: It probably will, thanks! I did not see it on the documentation so I thought it would not be possible...

messages.text: Yeah for some reason it's not listed in the documentation.

elements.text: Yeah for some reason it's not listed in the documentation.

messages.text: The command works. However, I was expecting that the package manager would not attempt to download packages that are already in the depot. It still does...

elements.text: The command works. However, I was expecting that the package manager would not attempt to download packages that are already in the depot. It still does...

elements.text: Their probably at different versions

elements.text: Yeah, that must be the case somehow.

messages.text: Still strange. I instantiated a package environment that includes a manifest. The package is fully functional when used from that env. Then, I try to dev the package in the main env and it still tries to download.

elements.text: Still strange. I instantiated a package environment that includes a manifest. The package is fully functional when used from that env. Then, I try to dev the package in the main env and it still tries to download.

messages.text: When you dev a package, it doesn't look at the manifest of that package environment.

elements.text: When you dev a package, it doesn't look at the manifest of that package environment.

messages.text: If you are deving in the main environment, it only looks at the manifest if the main environment

elements.text: If you are deving in the main environment, it only looks at the manifest if the main environment

messages.text: In general, package operations in environment X will only look at the manifest of environment X. Not any other manifests.

elements.text: In general, package operations in environment X will only look at the manifest of environment X. Not any other manifests.

messages.text: So if you Pkg.develop in environment X, and you pass the preserve kwarg to Pkg.develop, then the preservation is done with respect to the manifest of environment X only

elements.text: So if you Pkg.develop in environment X, and you pass the preserve kwarg to Pkg.develop, then the preservation is done with respect to the manifest of environment X only

messages.text: Mmm. Perhaps I should use the offline mode of the package manager then.

elements.text: Mmm. Perhaps I should use the offline mode of the package manager then.

messages.text: Yeah that might work. Just do `Pkg.offline(true)`

elements.text: Yeah that might work. Just do
Pkg.offline(true)

messages.text: Just out of curiosity, is your main environment empty? Or do you have other stuff in it?

elements.text: Just out of curiosity, is your main environment empty? Or do you have other stuff in it?

messages.text: It is pretty much empty, but not completely.

elements.text: It is pretty much empty, but not completely.

messages.text: Yeah so in that case, if you do Pkg.develop in the main environment, and you pass the preserve kwarg as PRESERVE_all, then Pkg is forced to preserve the current manifest in the main environment. So in the main environment, you have additional constraints. In the package environment, you don't have those constraints. So it makes sense that the two different environments might resolve to different sets of versions.

elements.text: Yeah so in that case, if you do Pkg.develop in the main environment, and you pass the preserve kwarg as PRESERVE_all, then Pkg is forced to preserve the current manifest in the main environment. So in the main environment, you have additional constraints. In the package environment, you don't have those constraints. So it makes sense that the two different environments might resolve to different sets of versions.

messages.text: Anyway, if your main interest is to minimize the number of downloads, then `Pkg.offline(true)` is probably your best bet.

elements.text: Anyway, if your main interest is to minimize the number of downloads, then
Pkg.offline(true)
is probably your best bet.

messages.text: Got it. Thanks a lot for your help!

elements.text: Got it. Thanks a lot for your help!

[January 26th, 2021 6:16 PM] mmiller212365: I'm having some difficulty understanding how `LOAD_PATH` works. If I push a directory to it that has a `Manifest.toml`, the dependencies of that directory are accessible. If I delete the `Manifest.toml` from that directory, the dependencies are not accessible. At least I think this is what is happening...

Is this expected or not? The related issue is: <https://github.com/JuliaTesting/TestReports.jl/issues/53> if anyone's interested. I'm trying to ensure that the dependencies of `TestReports` are in the sandbox environment used to generate the test reports for other packages. Cheers!
attachments.text:
I'm having some difficulty understanding how `LOAD_PATH` works. If I push a directory to it that has a `Manifest.toml`, the dependencies of that directory are accessible. If I delete the `Manifest.toml` from that directory, the dependencies are not accessible. At least I think this is what is happening...

Is this expected or not? The related issue is: <https://github.com/JuliaTesting/TestReports.jl/issues/53> if anyone's interested. I'm trying to ensure that the dependencies of `TestReports` are in the sandbox environment used to generate the test reports for other packages. Cheers!

I’m seeing a weird issue in a class I teach. Students with new M1 Macbooks seem to have issues instantiating some packages. I can’t reproduce since I have an older Mac.

They activated/instantiated the Project.toml in <https://github.com/jlchan/caam452_s21/tree/main/hw1> (just adds UnicodePlots.jl and GarbageMath.jl). They get the error “expected package to be registered”

Has anyone else run into this? Would anyone with an M1 Mac be willing to reproduce this issue?

messages.text:
Hi folks, I'm new to the language so excuse me for asking what seems like a dumb question.

Let's say I'm working on a package in its own environment that I have activated. I want to debug my code so I install Debugger.jl. Debugger is now added as a dependency to the project's toml file, yet my package doesn't depend on it. Is there a way of adding a package to an environment without registering it as a project dependency? Should I keep my Debugger.jl in another environment and have my package installed there via the dev command? What is the best practice? I tried googling the answer before asking but I wasn't succesful.

elements.text:
Hi folks, I'm new to the language so excuse me for asking what seems like a dumb question.

Let's say I'm working on a package in its own environment that I have activated. I want to debug my code so I install Debugger.jl. Debugger is now added as a dependency to the project's toml file, yet my package doesn't depend on it. Is there a way of adding a package to an environment without registering it as a project dependency? Should I keep my Debugger.jl in another environment and have my package installed there via the dev command? What is the best practice? I tried googling the answer before asking but I wasn't succesful.

messages.text: You can keep Debugger.jl in the "default" environment and still load it from the REPL.

elements.text: You can keep Debugger.jl in the "default" environment and still load it from the REPL.

messages.text: So you have packages like Debugger, Revise, BenchmarkTools in the default environment for interactive use

elements.text: So you have packages like Debugger, Revise, BenchmarkTools in the default environment for interactive use

messages.text: even if the default environment is not active?

elements.text: even if the default environment is not active?

messages.text: Yes, there is a "stack" of environment from which you can load packages from in the REPL (called `LOAD_PATH`).

elements.text: Yes, there is a "stack" of environment from which you can load packages from in the REPL (called
LOAD_PATH

messages.text: You can modify that stack to your liking but by default it also contains the default environment

elements.text: You can modify that stack to your liking but by default it also contains the default environment

messages.text: Wow you're right it works

elements.text: Wow you're right it works

messages.text: It never occurred to me just try importing Debugger because I assumed that the environments were isolated from one another

elements.text: It never occurred to me just try importing Debugger because I assumed that the environments were isolated from one another

messages.text: Thank you :pray:

elements.text: Thank you

messages.text: Hello all, I have a reproducible issue from the Pkg server on 1.6-beta.  I have a package I want the latest version of, namely AWSS3 0.8.3.  Looking in the registry, it is indeed there.  If I look at the registry that Pkg server clones for me, it's not there however.  Even if I delete it, the registry it refreshes with doesn't have it.  I can resolve this by deleting the registry, disabling pkg server, and using the one cloned from git, or by manually cloning from git.  Nothing I have done seems to have been able to resolve the issue through pkg serve

elements.text: Hello all, I have a reproducible issue from the Pkg server on 1.6-beta.  I have a package I want the latest version of, namely AWSS3 0.8.3.  Looking in the registry, it is indeed there.  If I look at the registry that Pkg server clones for me, it's not there however.  Even if I delete it, the registry it refreshes with doesn't have it.  I can resolve this by deleting the registry, disabling pkg server, and using the one cloned from git, or by manually cloning from git.  Nothing I have done seems to have been able to resolve the issue through pkg serve

messages.text:
I ran into a "fun" bit of CI pain yesterday that might be worth noting, so I'm writing it here:

How `Pkg.Registry.add(RegistrySpec(url=...))` deals with missing credentials on Windows vs. Ubuntu/MacOS seems to differ (probably only in non-interactive settings). On Ubuntu/MacOS, if the credentials are not around I get an error
```    Cloning registry from "<the-registry-I-was-trying-to-add>"
ERROR: failed to clone from <the-registry-I-was-trying-to-add>, error: GitError(Code:EUSER, Class:Callback, Aborting, user cancelled credential request.)
...```
But on Windows, it seems to simply hang around indefinitely, waiting for me to type in my credentials.
This had the not-so-fun consequence of eating up 12 hours of CI time on my private Github profile; that's a lesson learned..!

elements.text:

messages.text:
is there a way to debug Pkg installing large artifacts?
```(PyJl) pkg> add LLVM_full_jll
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
   Resolving package versions...
 Downloading artifact: LLVM_full```
Has shown the progress bar of the download up to 100%, and now it's stuck like this since 2 hours... (1.6rc1).

I tried twice, and it always ends up like that.

elements.text: is there a way to debug Pkg installing large artifacts?

(PyJl) pkg> add LLVM_full_jll
    Updating registry at `~/.julia/registries/General`
   Resolving package versions...
 Downloading artifact: LLVM_full

Has shown the progress bar of the download up to 100%, and now it's stuck like this since 2 hours... (1.6rc1).

I tried twice, and it always ends up like that.

messages.text: Try `ENV["JULIA_PKG_SERVER"] = ""` before downloading

elements.text: Try
ENV["JULIA_PKG_SERVER"] = ""
before downloading

messages.text: The Pkg servers are pretty stable so it is more likely to be <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Downloads.jl/issues/95|https://github.com/JuliaLang/Downloads.jl/issues/95>

elements.text: The Pkg servers are pretty stable so it is more likely to be
https://github.com/JuliaLang/Downloads.jl/issues/95

messages.text: Hm, but the artifact downloads are not async and we shouldn't put the same URLs to download like in the MWE there?

elements.text: Hm, but the artifact downloads are not async and we shouldn't put the same URLs to download like in the MWE there?

messages.text: But I had seen the progress bar get to 100%

elements.text: But I had seen the progress bar get to 100%

messages.text: <@U67D54KS8> that did it, thank you

messages.text: Asking for a friend: Is there a way to “install” a Julia script so you can call it frrom the command line as e.g. `julia myscript.jl 1 2 3 a b c`?

elements.text: Asking for a friend: Is there a way to “install” a Julia script so you can call it frrom the command line as e.g.
julia myscript.jl 1 2 3 a b c

messages.text: That script would call functions in a package but needs to do some processing of the command line arguments. Or what is the correct way to do this?
